case_vignette: A 21-year-old man comes to the military base physician for evaluation of progressive discomfort in his right shoulder for the past 4 months. He joined the military 6 months ago and is part of a drill team. In anticipation of an upcoming competition, he has been practicing rifle drills and firing exercises 8 hours a day. Physical examination shows tenderness to palpation and a firm mass in the superior part of the right deltopectoral groove. Range of motion is limited by pain and stiffness.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been having growing pain and discomfort in my right shoulder for the past 4 months.
How old are you?
I am 21 years old.
Have you recently experienced any injury or trauma to your shoulder?
No, I haven't had any injury or trauma, just regular practice for the drill team.
Do you have any history of joint or bone problems in your family?
I don't know about any family history of joint or bone problems.
Do you have any other symptoms such as fever, weight loss, or night sweats?
No, I don't have any of those symptoms.
Have you been taking any medications for the pain or discomfort in your shoulder?
I haven't mentioned taking any medications.

Based on your symptoms and history, it's important to consider the possibility of rotator cuff tendonitis. However, further evaluation and imaging may be necessary to confirm the diagnosis. I recommend visiting a healthcare professional.

Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been having this annoying discomfort in my right shoulder that's been getting worse over the past 4 months.
Could you tell me if you have experienced any injury or trauma to your shoulder recently?
No, I haven't had any specific injury or trauma, just lots of rifle drills and firing exercises for my military drill team practice.
Do you have any other symptoms apart from the discomfort in your right shoulder? Any weakness, numbness, or tingling in your arm or hand?
No, I don't have any weakness, numbness, or tingling; just pain and stiffness when I try to move my shoulder.
Have you had any similar episodes of shoulder pain in the past, and have you sought medical attention for this issue before?
No, this is the first time I'm having this kind of shoulder pain and I haven't seen a doctor for it before.
Are you currently taking any medications, either over-the-counter or prescription, for any other medical conditions?
No, I'm not taking any medications right now.
All right. Do you have a family history of any joint or musculoskeletal conditions, such as arthritis or tendinitis?
I'm not aware of any family history of joint or musculoskeletal conditions.

Thank you. Based on your symptoms and history of repetitive rifle drills and firing exercises, as well as the absence of injury, I suspect you may be experiencing **shoulder impingement syndrome**. I recommend you seek an evaluation from a medical professional to confirm the diagnosis and discuss appropriate treatment options.

trial_1.summarized_conversation: A military drill team member presents to the clinic with a persistent discomfort in their right shoulder.
